NarrativeWQG: No statistically significant decrease in pH from background when pH is less than 6.5.  No restriction on the increase in pH except in boggy areas that have a unique fauna or flora.  Site-specific ambient water quality objectives to restrict the pH increase in areas with a unique fauna and flora are recommended.
Reference: B.C. Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy

NarrativeWQG: Unrestricted change permitted within a pH range of 6.5 to 9.  The component of the freshwater WQGs should be used cautiously if the pH change causes the carbon dioxide concentrations to exceed a 10 umol/L minimum or a 1360 umol/L short-term.  Carbon dioxide concentrations below 10 umol/L can cause a shift in the phytoplankton community to cyanobacteria, while carbon dioxide concentrations above 1360 umol/L can be toxic to fish.
Reference: B.C. Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy

NarrativeWQG: No statistically significant increase in pH from background when pH is above 9.  Short-term increases (2-3 days) to pH 9.5 are permitted for lake restoration projects.  Decreases in pH are permittes as long as carbon dioxide concentrations are not elevated above 1360 umol/L.  Carbon dioxide concentrations above 1360 umol/L may be toxic to fish.
Reference: B.C. Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy

NarrativeWQG: Unrestricted change when pH is greater than 7 and less than 8.7 to protect mollusc embryo development.
